Unpromoted cobalt-silica gel catalysts Hui Ming, Bruce G. Baker * The School of Physical Sciences, The Flinders University of South Australia G.P~O. Box 2100, Adelaide, South Australia 5001, Australia Received 3 February 1994: revised 1 August 1994; accepted 28 September 1994 Abstract The effect of preparation conditions on cobalt-silica gel catalysts has been investigated by tem- perature-programmed reduction, differential thermal analysis, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, and magnetic susceptibility measurements. The results have been correlated with the performance of the catalysts for the conversion of syngas. It has been found that active Fischer-Tropsch (F-T) cobalt catalysts can be partially or totally reduced to the metal phase during activation. However, reducibility of the catalysts is a necessary but not sufficient characteristic in ensuring good activity. The pH of the impregnating solution influences surface charge and solubility of silica gel. Consequently, the physical and chemical properties of the cobalt species on the surface of silica gel are strongly affected by this parameter. At pH < 5 cobalt deposits as a cation. At pH < 2 the silica surface is positively charged so that the dispersion of cobalt and consequently catalytic activity are poor. At pH >/5, cobalt reacts to form silicates or hydrosilicates which are irreducible. Active catalysts are shown to adsorb hydrogen by spillover on to the silica support. Keywords: Catalyst characterization (TPR/DTA/XPS); Cobalt-silica; Fischer-Tropsch; Spillover; Syngas conversion 1. Introduction Cobalt was first employed as a Fischer-Tropsch (F-T) synthesis catalyst in the early stages of attempts to convert hydrogen and carbon monoxide into hydrocar- bons. The F-T catalyst with cobalt as the major catalytic component is well known for its low water-gas shift activity and moderate reaction conditions [ 1]. These characteristics result in efficient utilization of carbon monoxide and a relatively low external operation cost. However, because cobalt is more costly than iron, the * Corresponding author. Tel. (+61-8) 2012228, fax. (+61-8) 2013035. 0926-860X/95/$09.50 1995 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved SSDIO926-860X (94) 00220-7 24 H. Ming, B.G. Baker~Applied Catalysis A: General 123 (1995) 23-36 development of lightly loaded supported catalysts for the F-T synthesis has received much attention. Silica gel and kieselguhr are the most common supports. Most previous studies have focused on physical or physicochemical properties of surface cobalt species, such as dispersion, distribution, and morphology and their effects on catalytic activity [2-15]. Although some studies have considered the contribution of silica gel to such a catalytic system, in most cases silica gel has been regarded as support material supplying a high surface area for dispersion of the active component [ 14,15 ]. Silica gel, although relatively chemically inert, reacts strongly with cobalt species at high temperatures to form a variety of cobalt silicates [ 16]. Both the surface electronic charge of the silica gel and its ion exchange behaviour in an aqueous solution may significantly affect the interaction between cobalt and silica gel [17,18]. In this study a systematic investigation of the properties of unpromoted cobalt- silica gel catalysts, prepared at different pH of the impregnating solution, was performed by means of various techniques. The characteristics have been correlated with the performance of the catalysts for the conversion of syngas. 2. Experimental 2.1. Preparation of catalysts Catalysts were prepared by direct solution impregnation (incipient wetness vol- ume method). The silica gel support saturated with cobalt nitrate solution was agitated in an ultrasonic bath for 15 min. This was followed by drying in a micro- wave oven for 30 min and calcination in a muffle furnace either at 320 or at 520 for 2 h. The grain size of the silica gel support was 125-150/zm (Aldrich Chemicals grade 62). This material had a surface area of ca. 250 m2 g- 1 and a mean pore diameter of 14 nm. Cobalt solutions were prepared from analytically pure Co(NO3)2.6H20. Other chemicals used in this study were AR grade. The hydrogen and nitrogen employed were of 99.99% purity. The air used for differ- ential thermal analysis (DTA) was purified by passing it through molecular sieves and silica gel traps. 2.2. Apparatus and procedures DTA measurements were conducted using a Shimadzu DT-30 instrument. The catalyst precursor was placed in the furnace and heated in a stream of air to the desired temperature (320 or 520) at a heating rate of 20 min ~ and held at this temperature for 2 h. This treatment simulated the catalysts calcination process. Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) apparatus used in the present work was constructed in this laboratory and was based on previously published designs H. Ming, B.G. Baker~Applied Catalysis A: General 123 (1995) 23-36 25 [19,20]. A carefully designed gas flow system, equipped with precise pressure regulators, variable constant differential flow controllers and a U-shape gas mixer, provided the system with a stable H2/N2 gas mixture. The mixture was passed through a tube containing reduced cobalt catalyst heated at ca. 200 to convert any possible traces of oxygen to water. The water vapour and other gaseous impu- rities were condensed at a cold trap ( - 100*C) before reaching the reference cell of the thermal conductivity detector (TCD), which was used to monitor changes in the gas composition before and after reduction. The reactor tube was made of silica (4 mm I.D.) seated in a 8 mm I.D. tube furnace which could be heated to 1000. After the gas mixture passed through the reactor, a second cold trap ( - 100) collected reduction products to protect the detector from contamination. TPR measurements were performed using a 96:4 N2/H2 gas mixture (51 ml min i ) at a heating rate of 22 rain- 1. The output of the detector was connected to a chart recorder and a computer. In order to distinguish hydrogen uptake due to reduction of the sample from hydrogen adsorption, a cyclic TPR procedure was developed. The principle of this procedure is to repeatedly run TPR tests on a sample. Peaks which are reproducible in a cycle are interpreted as due to adsorption. A Philips PW/1050 diffractometer equipped with a fine focus cobalt tube ( 1500 W, 60 kV) was used to obtain X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns over the range of 20= 25-75 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra were recorded using a Perkin- Elmer 5400 surface analysis system equipped with an A1 Kc~ radiation source. The Si 2p3/2 photoemission line (BE= 103.5 eV) was taken as a reference to correct for electrostatic charging. Magnetic susceptibility measurements were performed by a modified Gouy bal- ance ( Sherwood Scientific). Each sample was reduced in a tube furnace in hydrogen overnight and then sealed at both ends without any exposure to the air. The magnetic susceptibility of a reduced sample was measured at room temperature. Cobalt-silica gel catalysts were tested in a fixed-bed micro reactor. The catalyst was activated in a stream of hydrogen at 320 for 16 h. Most of the reaction tests were conducted under a pressure of 800 kPa at 260 or 280 in the stream of CO/H2 = 1 and at a space velocity of 900 h i. Products were analyzed by gas chromatography. 3. Discussion The results demonstrate that catalytic activity, reduction behaviour and colour of a cobalt on silica gel catalyst, prepared by the direct solution impregnation method, depend strongly upon the initial pH of the solution. The interpretation of the results requires consideration of the nature of the silica gel-aqueous solution interface and the ion-exchange properties of the support. When silica gel is impregnated with an ionic solution, adsorption of ions is strongly affected by the surface charge. The protonation-deprotonation equilibria and adsorption of hydroxyl complexes derived from the hydrolysis products of partially dissolved silica gel affect the resultant concentration of the charged surface groups [ 17,18]. Both processes involve H+ and OH ions and thus are controlled by the pH of the solution. Previous studies have revealed that the pH of the aqueous solution, the type and strength of other ions, as well as the impurities present in the solid can all have substantial effects on the surface charge of silica gel [26,27]. The pH of the impregnating solution is the most important adjustable factor. For silica gel, a pH value defined as the point of zero charge (PZC) is between 2 and 3.5 [26,27 ]. Below the pH of the PZC, the surface of silica gel is positively charged. Since cobalt ions are positively charged in aqueous solution, such a surface does not favour adsorption. At pH above the PZC, deposition is enhanced. Silica gel at pH >/5 partially dissolves and ion exchange processes occur. This ion exchange may involve metallic ions directly substituting for silicon at the 34 H. Ming, B.G. Baker~Applied Catalysis A: General I23 (1995) 23-36 surface of silica gel to form new charged centres [ 17,18]. The mechanism of the deposition of cobalt ions can therefore be expected to depend strongly on pH. If the preparation of a cobalt-silica gel catalyst is carried out in a basic solution, it is possible that silicates may form. Catalyst No. 809 was prepared at pH = 1.8 at which the surface of silica gel is positively charged. Consequently, the deposited cobalt species were not well dis- persed at the silica gel surface. The TPR and XRD results demonstrate that cobalt oxide was present at the surface of this catalyst. Catalyst No. 810 was prepared at pH = 4.6 at which the silica gel surface is slightly negatively charged. In this case, the attraction forces favour adsorption of the positive cobalt ions. Consequently, cobalt is expected to be well dispersed at the surface. The activity of this catalyst was superior to No. 809. However, since the interaction of cobalt with the support is still fairly weak, the activity of the catalyst is decreased by calcination at 520. Catalysts No. 806 and No. 798 were prepared at pH at 5.0 and 6.3, respectively, using urea to form a complex. UV spectroscopy of these solutions indicated that cobalt was present as Co". In this pH range, the cationic exchange between silica gel and cobalt ions present in the solution is a predominant process. The deposition mechanism involves a surface chemical reaction. The TPR, DTA and XPS results have suggested that the cobalt species present at the surface of those catalysts were silicates or hydrosilicates and their stability was dependent on the temperature of calcination. The composition of surface silicates was pH dependent. Both catalysts showed low F-T activity because their reducibility is low. The excess hydrogen consumed in the reduction of No. 798 is apparently associated with the decompo- sition of the urea complex. Catalyst No. 808 was prepared at pH = 10 using ethylenediamine as a complexing agent. Cobalt in the complex existed initially as Co2 + but it was quickly oxidized to Co3+. At this pH, partial surface dissolution of silica gel and ion-exchange processes are predominant. Consequently, the surface structure of silica gel can also be affected. The TPR, DTA and XPS results confirmed formation of cobalt silicates. The activity of this catalyst in the F-T synthesis was comparable to that of catalyst No. 810, even though only 26% of the cobalt was reduced during activation. The measurement of hydrogen adsorption on activated catalysts recorded in Table 4 and Fig. 3 correlate well with the catalytic activities. The catalysts which are reduced below 400 contain metallic cobalt. They adsorb hydrogen reversibly in the temperature range 100-300. The first peak ( < 200) in each trace of Fig. 3 is attributed to dissociative adsorption of hydrogen on cobalt. Previous studies of supported cobalt catalysts have shown that the adsorption of hydrogen is activated and reversible and that the maximum adsorption occurs above 100 [ 14,28,29]. The temperature of the maximum uptake in Fig. 3 is dependent on the rate of heating and occurs at lower temperature for slower rates. The same adsorption characteristic is observed for reduced cobalt oxide and to a small extent for No. 808 (Table 4). No such adsorption was observed for No. 806 and No. 798. H. Ming, B.G. Baker~Applied Catalysis A: General 123 (1995)23-36 35 The second peak of hydrogen adsorption above 200 is attributed to 'spillover' hydrogen on the silica support. This adsorption was not observed for reduced cobalt oxide but was strongly evident for No. 808 (Table 4). Many examples of the bonding of hydrogen on silica and other oxide supports by spillover following dissociative adsorption on a metal have been reviewed [30]. The effect has been observed on cobalt-alumina catalysts [ 31 ]. The process is activated and the exper- iments show that for cobalt-silica it is reversible. The migration of monohydrogen from the metal to the silica is believed to involve surface hydroxyl groups. The loss of the second peak (Fig. 3B, trace 4) after heating No. 810 to 500 is presumably due to loss of surface sites in the silica rather than to loss of cobalt. The experiments in which the cooling cycle was limited to ca. 120 showed no further uptake of hydrogen. This shows that both forms of adsorbed hydrogen are stable over the temperature range to 300. The catalytic behaviour shown in Table 2 can be explained in the following terms: No. 808 and No. 810 both contained metallic cobalt and spillover hydrogen; No. 810 had the better dispersion of cobalt. The activity of No. 810 was decreased by calcination at 520 because this destroyed spillover sites on the silica. The activity of No. 808 was high despite the relatively small amount of reducible cobalt because of the high content of spillover hydrogen. Both No. 808 and No. 798 were inactive because they did not contain reduced cobalt. 5. Conclusions The catalytic performance of a cobalt-silica gel F-T catalyst is strongly affected by preparation conditions. The pH of the impregnating solution is the most signif- icant parameter. For catalysts prepared at pH <5, cobalt is deposited onto the surface of silica gel mainly by adsorption. Dispersion of the adsorbed cobalt species is strongly affected by the surface charge. At pH < 2, the silica gel surface is positively charged and, consequently, cobalt is poorly dispersed. At pH = 2-5, when the surface of silica gel is negatively charged, adsorption is favoured and dispersion of cobalt enhanced. For catalysts prepared at pH/> 5, cobalt ions readily react with the surface of silica gel to form various cobalt silicates or hydrosilicates. Because these are not reduced during activation, the amount of metallic cobalt available for the F-T synthesis is small, so the activity of the catalyst is low. Active catalysts were shown to adsorb hydrogen at the reduction temperature. Spillover hydrogen on the silica support has been identified as an important char- acteristic of the reactive catalyst. The effect of preparation conditions on cobalt-silica gel catalysts has been investigated by temperature-programmed reduction, differential thermal analysis, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, and magnetic susceptibility measurements. The results have been correlated with the performance of the catalysts for the conversion of syngas. It has been found that active Fischer-Tropsch (F-T) cobalt catalysts can be partially or totally reduced to the metal phase during activation. However, reducibility of the catalysts is a necessary but not sufficient characteristic in ensuring good activity. The pH of the impregnating solution influences surface charge and solubility of silica gel. Consequently, the physical and chemical properties of the cobalt species on the surface of silica gel are strongly affected by this parameter. At pH<5 cobalt deposits as a cation. At pH<2 the silica surface is positively charged so that the dispersion of cobalt and consequently catalytic activity are poor. At pH≥5, cobalt reacts to form silicates or hydrosilicates which are irreducible. Active catalysts are shown to adsorb hydrogen by spillover on to the silica support.
